description: Macro sensitivity rubric for 11 GICS sectors. For each sector, defines which macro indicators are relevant and whether the sector benefits (+1) or is hurt (-1) when the indicator is above the threshold.
scoring_method: For each sector, sum the signals across its relevant indicators. Each indicator contributes +1 if the condition is favorable (indicator above threshold and direction is 'high_favorable', or below threshold and direction is 'low_favorable') and -1 otherwise. The raw score range is [-N, +N] where N is the number of indicators for that sector.

sensitivities.rationale: Energy demand is pro-cyclical; strong GDP growth drives higher consumption of oil, gas, and refined products.
Energy companies are natural inflation beneficiaries because commodity prices are a primary driver of headline inflation; rising prices flow directly to revenue.
A current account surplus often signals a net energy/commodity exporter, which creates a supportive macro environment for domestic energy firms (favorable FX, reinvestment flows).
Energy projects require long-horizon capital commitments; political instability raises expropriation and contract risk, deterring investment and compressing valuations.
Materials demand (metals, chemicals, construction inputs) is strongly tied to industrial and construction activity, which tracks GDP.
Like energy, materials companies benefit from rising commodity prices that drive inflation; they are price-makers in inflationary environments.
High FDI inflows signal capital formation and infrastructure build-out, which directly increases demand for raw materials.
Low unemployment signals tight labor markets and strong economic activity, both of which support industrial materials demand.
Industrials (capital goods, transportation, construction) are the textbook cyclical sector; revenue is directly tied to economic expansion.
Low unemployment reflects strong labor demand, which correlates with high capacity utilization and capital spending -- both direct drivers of industrial revenue.
Industrials are capital-intensive and rely on debt financing for equipment and projects; tight credit spreads reduce funding costs and support order flow.
A steep yield curve signals expected economic expansion and accommodative near-term monetary policy, both favorable for capex-dependent industrials.
Foreign direct investment flows into manufacturing, logistics, and infrastructure, directly benefiting industrial firms.
Discretionary spending (autos, retail, travel) is the most income-elastic consumer category; it expands sharply in booms and contracts in downturns.
Employment is the primary determinant of consumer confidence and disposable income; low unemployment supports discretionary purchases.
High inflation erodes real purchasing power and compresses discretionary margins (input costs rise faster than firms can reprice non-essential goods).
Many discretionary purchases (autos, housing-adjacent goods) are credit-financed; lower rates reduce consumer borrowing costs and support demand.
Many discretionary retailers and auto companies are sub-investment-grade borrowers; wide spreads raise their cost of capital and signal risk-off sentiment.
While staples have pricing power, extreme inflation compresses margins in the short term (input cost lags) and can trigger government price controls in emerging markets.
Staples companies need functioning distribution networks and consumer access; instability disrupts supply chains and reduces store traffic.
Staples are bond proxies (stable dividends, low growth); high rates make bonds more attractive on a relative yield basis, compressing staples valuations.
Government is the dominant payer in most health systems; high debt burdens lead to austerity, price regulation, and delayed procurement -- all negative for health care revenues.
Health care investment (hospitals, clinical trials, regulatory approvals) requires institutional stability; instability deters pharma entry and disrupts reimbursement systems.
Biotech and med-tech are long-duration growth assets whose valuations are highly sensitive to discount rates; lower rates support higher present values of future cash flows.
While health care is defensive, GDP growth expands the tax base and supports government health budgets, enabling faster adoption of new treatments and devices.
Banks earn net interest margin by borrowing short and lending long; a steep curve directly widens this margin. This is the single most important macro signal for bank profitability.
Loan growth, fee income, and asset quality all improve with economic expansion; recessions trigger credit losses that overwhelm margin benefits.
Unemployment is the strongest predictor of consumer loan defaults; low unemployment keeps credit quality high and provisions low.
Wide credit spreads signal systemic credit stress, which impairs bank loan books, reduces capital markets revenue, and tightens interbank liquidity.
Financial systems depend on institutional trust, rule of law, and contract enforcement; instability triggers capital flight and bank runs.
Enterprise IT spending is pro-cyclical; companies invest in technology during expansions and cut capex in downturns.
Technology stocks are long-duration growth equities; lower discount rates mechanically increase the present value of distant future earnings, supporting valuations.
Tech sectors in emerging and mid-income countries depend heavily on foreign capital for growth; high FDI signals an attractive investment environment for technology firms.
IP-intensive technology businesses require rule of law, patent enforcement, and regulatory predictability; instability deters investment and talent.
Advertising revenue (a major component for media and interactive companies) is strongly pro-cyclical; telecom subscriber growth also tracks economic expansion.
Telecom companies carry significant debt for network buildouts; media/interactive companies are growth stocks with rate-sensitive valuations.
Consumer spending on subscriptions, streaming, and mobile services is supported by employment and income growth.
Communication infrastructure requires large fixed investments and regulatory licenses; instability raises the risk of expropriation, censorship mandates, or license revocation.

Utilities are the classic bond proxy: high dividend yield, regulated returns, heavy leverage. Rising rates increase their cost of debt and make their yields less competitive versus risk-free alternatives.
Regulated utilities often face price caps or regulatory lag that prevents passing through cost increases in real-time; high inflation compresses real returns.
Highly indebted governments may impose windfall taxes, delay rate approvals, or force utilities to absorb subsidy burdens, impairing returns.
Utilities operate under long-term concessions and regulated tariff structures; political instability threatens contract sanctity and regulatory frameworks.
Real estate is the most rate-sensitive sector: REITs use significant leverage, property values are discounted cash flow models, and mortgage rates directly affect demand. This is the dominant signal.
Economic growth drives office and retail leasing demand, residential absorption, and rental rate growth.
Employment growth drives housing formation (new households) and office space absorption; high unemployment leads to vacancy and rent concessions.
Real estate developers and REITs are heavy borrowers; wide spreads increase refinancing risk and reduce transaction volume (buyers and sellers cannot agree on cap rates).
While real estate is sometimes called an inflation hedge, high inflation triggers rate hikes that dominate; in practice, real estate underperforms during inflationary tightening cycles.
